Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Story:
Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s a ritual—one I know means a lot to them, especially since I moved out for work. Tonight, though, my mind is elsewhere. My mentor, Dr. Lee, sent me a list of articles to read. “No rush,” she said, but I know she expects me to be prepared for our next meeting. The reading isn’t due for weeks, but I want to impress her, to show I’m committed.

As I stare at my phone, I see the time ticking closer to when I usually call home. My parents will be waiting, probably already sitting together, eager to hear about my week. But the articles are open on my laptop, and I feel the pressure to get ahead, to not let Dr. Lee down. I can’t focus on either task, guilt gnawing at me. If I call my parents, I’ll be distracted, thinking about the reading. If I dive into the articles, I’ll imagine my parents’ disappointment when the phone doesn’t ring. I sit at my desk, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation to meet first.
